sections.title: Albania Introduction
content: Albania is a country in Southeast Europe on the Adriatic and Ionian Seas, bordered by Montenegro, Kosovo, North Macedonia, and Greece. Known for its stunning coastline, rich history, and developing economy, Albania offers unique opportunities for businesses looking to expand in the Balkans region.

sections.title: What to Know about Albania's Geography
content: Albania is located in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula. The capital, Tirana, is situated in the center of the country. Albania features diverse geography including coastal plains, mountains, and rivers, with the Albanian Alps in the north being particularly noteworthy.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Albania
content: Albanian is the official language of Albania. English and Italian are widely spoken, especially in business contexts and tourism sectors.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: An employee's salary is paid in Albanian Lek (ALL), the national currency, by default. If the employee works abroad, the salary can be paid in the currency specified in the individual employment contract. The parties can agree on the salary payment in foreign currency at an exchange rate agreed upon by both parties. Salary payment can be transferred to the employee's account at a payment service provider, with the respective services paid from the employer's account.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers in Albania are required to maintain accurate records of working hours, overtime, and leave. Employees must submit timesheets as per company policy, and records must be kept for at least 5 years for labor inspection purposes.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees in Albania are entitled to a minimum of 4 weeks (20 working days) of paid annual leave per year. Additional days may be granted based on years of service, specific job conditions, or collective agreements.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 365 days of maternity leave, with at least 35 days taken before the expected birth date. Maternity benefits are paid through social insurance. Parental leave provisions are also available for adoptive parents.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to paternity leave in Albania. The duration and payment conditions are regulated by labor law and may vary based on specific circumstances and employment agreements.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents in Albania are entitled to leave similar to biological parents, with specific provisions outlined in the Labor Code to support the integration of adopted children into families.

sections.title: Kosovo Introduction
content: Kosovo is a partially recognized state in Southeast Europe, bordered by Serbia, North Macedonia, Albania, and Montenegro. It declared independence in 2008 and has been developing its economy with a focus on services, trade, and increasingly, technology sectors.

sections.title: What to Know about Kosovo's Geography
content: Kosovo is landlocked in the central Balkan Peninsula. The capital, Pristina, is located in the northeastern part of the country. Kosovo's terrain is predominantly mountainous with the Sharr Mountains in the south and the Kosovo Plain in the east.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Kosovo
content: Albanian and Serbian are the official languages of Kosovo. English is increasingly common, especially among younger generations and in business settings.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Employee salaries in Kosovo are typically paid in Euros (EUR), the official currency used in the country. Payment is usually made through bank transfer to the employee's designated account. Employers must ensure timely payment according to the employment contract terms, typically on a monthly basis.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers are required to maintain accurate records of working hours, including overtime and leave. Employees must submit timesheets according to company policy to ensure proper compensation. All employment records must be kept for inspection by the Labor Inspectorate.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees in Kosovo are entitled to a minimum of 20 working days of paid annual leave per year. Additional leave days may be provided based on the employment contract, collective agreements, or company policy. Leave must be scheduled in coordination with the employer.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 12 months of maternity leave, with 6 weeks mandatory before the expected birth date. Maternity benefits are provided through the social insurance system. Parental leave provisions are also available for adoptive parents under specific conditions.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers in Kosovo are entitled to paternity leave following the birth of a child. The duration and compensation are regulated by labor law. Paternity leave helps support family bonding and shared parental responsibilities.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents are entitled to leave similar to biological parents to facilitate the integration of the adopted child. The specific provisions are outlined in Kosovo's labor legislation. Both adoptive mothers and fathers may be eligible for adoption leave benefits.

sections.title: North Macedonia Introduction
content: North Macedonia is a landlocked country in Southeast Europe, bordered by Serbia, Kosovo, Bulgaria, Greece, and Albania. The country has a developing market economy with growing sectors in technology, manufacturing, and services.

sections.title: What to Know about North Macedonia's Geography
content: North Macedonia is located in the central Balkan Peninsula. The capital, Skopje, is situated in the northern part of the country. The terrain is predominantly mountainous, with fertile valleys and basins.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in North Macedonia
content: Macedonian is the official language. Albanian is also widely spoken, particularly in western regions. English is increasingly common in business contexts.

faqSection.sectionTitle: Important Information for North Macedonia Employees

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries in North Macedonia are paid in Macedonian Denar (MKD), the national currency. Payment is typically made through bank transfer to the employee's account on a monthly basis. Employers may agree with employees to pay salaries in foreign currency if specified in the employment contract.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers must maintain detailed records of working hours, overtime, and all types of leave. Employees are required to submit accurate timesheets in accordance with company procedures. Records must be kept for at least 5 years for inspection by the State Labor Inspectorate.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees are entitled to a minimum of 20 working days of paid annual leave per year. Additional days may be granted based on employment contract terms, years of service, or collective agreements. Leave scheduling should be coordinated with the employer to ensure business continuity.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 9 months of maternity leave, with at least 28 days taken before the expected birth date. Maternity benefits are provided through social security. Parental leave is also available to support childcare and can be shared between parents in certain circumstances.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers are entitled to 7 days of paid paternity leave following the birth of a child. This leave can be taken continuously or divided within the first 3 months after birth. Paternity leave is designed to support fathers in actively participating in early childcare.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents are entitled to leave similar to maternity and paternity leave to support the adoption process and child integration. The specific duration and conditions are outlined in labor legislation. Both adoptive mothers and fathers may qualify for adoption leave benefits.

sections.title: Romania Introduction
content: Romania is a country in Southeast Europe, bordered by Bulgaria, Serbia, Hungary, Ukraine, and Moldova, with access to the Black Sea. As an EU member since 2007, Romania has a fast-growing economy with strong IT and manufacturing sectors.

sections.title: What to Know about Romania's Geography
content: Romania is located in the northern part of the Balkan Peninsula. The capital, Bucharest, is in the southern part of the country. Romania features diverse geography including the Carpathian Mountains, the Danube River, and the Black Sea coast.

sections.title: Languages Spoken in Romania
content: Romanian is the official language. English is widely spoken, especially in business and urban areas, making Romania an attractive destination for international companies.

faqs.question: Salary Payment
faqs.answer: Salaries in Romania are paid in Romanian Leu (RON), the national currency. Payment is typically made through bank transfer on a monthly basis, with net salary transferred to the employee's account. The employment contract may specify different payment arrangements if agreed upon by both parties.

faqs.question: Timesheets & Record Keeping
faqs.answer: Employers are required to maintain accurate records of working time, including overtime, night work, and leave. Employees must submit timesheets as required by company policy and labor regulations. All employment records must be available for inspection by the Labor Inspectorate and kept for at least 5 years.

faqs.question: Annual Leave
faqs.answer: Employees in Romania are entitled to a minimum of 20 working days of paid annual leave per year. Additional leave days may be provided based on working conditions, years of service, or collective labor agreements. Leave must be scheduled and approved by the employer in advance.

faqs.question: Maternity & Parental Leave
faqs.answer: Female employees are entitled to 126 days of maternity leave, with 63 days taken before and 63 days after birth. Additionally, either parent can take parental leave until the child reaches 2 years old (or 3 years for children with disabilities). Maternity and parental benefits are provided through the social insurance system.

faqs.question: Paternity Leave
faqs.answer: Fathers in Romania are entitled to 15 working days of paid paternity leave following the birth of a child. This leave can be taken within 8 weeks from the child's birth. Paternity leave benefits are provided through social security to support fathers' involvement in early childcare.

faqs.question: Adoption Leave
faqs.answer: Adoptive parents are entitled to leave similar to biological parents, with provisions for both maternity-equivalent and parental leave. The leave duration depends on the age of the adopted child and specific circumstances. Both adoptive mothers and fathers may qualify for adoption leave benefits under Romanian labor law.
